p:slide.p:title: If you are in an XSLT 1.0 environment, upgrade
p:slide.p: The limitations of XSLT 1.0 will reduce the quality of your XSLT. There is no reason to use XSLT 1.0 at this time. Namespacing issues will be resolved; XPath 2 will lead to considerably simpler stylesheets; grouping is practical and comprehensible.
XSLT 3.0 was finalised and became a recommendation on 8th June 2017

p:slide.p:title: Take advantage of the built-in templates
p:slide.p: The built in templates can save a great deal of effort if used appropriately. Avoid the use of xsl:value-of for simple elements and attributes (using xsl:apply-templates instead). This will achieve the same effect in most cases and will make updates to the code considerably simpler.

p:slide.p:title: Avoid using xsl:for-each
p:slide.p: xsl:for-each can always be replaced with xsl-apply-templates. Working in a style that leads to the creation of many small templates will make maintenance simpler and will dramatically reduce the chances of a need to refactor the stylesheet.

p:slide.p:title: Avoid use of xsl:if
p:slide.p: xsl:if can almost always be replaced by a template that uses a predicate match. This encourages the use of small templates and matching. Small templates and extensive use of matching leads to fewer special cases. In turn, this leads to easier maintenance and easier to comprehend code.

p:slide.p:title: Avoid xsl:choose
p:slide.p: xsl:choose can almost always be replaced by a series of templates with predicates in the match statement. This encourages the use of small templates and matching.

p:slide.p:title: Use predicates in xsl:template match attributes
p:slide.p: A great deal of complex decision making code can be eliminated by the liberal use of predicates in xsl:template match attributes.

p:slide.p:title: Limit use of xsl:call-template
p:slide.p: Excessive use of xsl:call-template is usually indicative of problems (or of stylesheets written by someone with a procedural or object oriented programming background). It is appropriate to use when there is predefined output in multiple templates which can be refactored into a single template.
Using xsl:call-template along with parameters (especially tunnel parameters) can simplify and clarify code.

p:slide.p:title: Use variables for complex XPaths
p:slide.p: Variables are often optimised away by XSLT engines and, in any case, have no more overhead than an XPath expression they may replace. There are two situations in which the use of a variable is appropriate even if it isn't necessary.

Intermediate variables can greatly simplify the creation of a complex variable and make the code considerably more comprehensible to another developer who may be maintaining your stylesheet (or to yourself in six months' time).

p:slide.p:title: Consider global variables for complex reused XPaths
p:slide.p: Complex XPath statements can be an overhead to evaluate. If reused, consider a global variable. The code will be both shorter and closer to optimal.

p:slide.p:title: Multi-pass processing
p:slide.p: Where it is necessary to apply templates to the same content twice, modes must be used. The addition of modes to the approach described above enables any task to be accomplished.

Remember that the result applying a template in XSLT 2.0 is a sequence. The processing results can be stored in a variable if required. xsl:apply-templates operates on sequences, including those stored in variables. This technique can be used in XSLT 1.0 if the `node-set` function is available.

p:slide.p:title: Modal Processing
p:slide.p: It can be beneficial When building modular XSLT applications, to use modal templates as much as possible. This is particularly useful when you are creating templates that can be reused in other contexts. For example, a set of templates that process list or table structures might be reused although the content of those templates can be different across multiple source XML languages.

p:slide.p:title: Modal Processing
p:slide.p: These templates should be used via an xsl:import statement. The two later templates can be overridden for any particular input model whilst the base template will remain the same no matter what model is used.

In general, the approach is to create a template matching the current node for each distinct task that needs to be carried out. These can be overridden via xsl:import whenever necessary without any changes to the library code at all.

If you have a content model that is reused across multiple schemas with distinct namespaces (but the same model), this technique can be combined with the previous one to create a consistent namespace for processing content.

p:slide.p:title: Use xsl:import
p:slide.p: Modularised XSLT is a good idea. It is tempting to use (the obvious) xsl:include to achieve modularisation. You will achieve better results if you use xsl:import instead. Any stylsheet included via xsl:import has lower precedence than one loaded with xsl:include . Stylesheets loaded using xsl:include have the same precedence as the importing stylesheeet. This means that included stylesheets cannot be treated as libraries of patterns to be overridden as necessary â€” overriding them leads to unpredictable results at best and errors at worst (you cannot override a named template for example).

p:slide.p:title: Summary - XSLT Design Patterns
p:slide.p: The rules above suggest the use of a "rule-based" xslt design (ref Michael Kay). Stylesheets should consist, as much as possible, of xsl:template statements and xsl:apply-template statements.

The use of complex predicates on the templates reduces the number of xsl:apply-templates statements where a select attribute is required. Output should be suppressed by the use of empty templates where required.
The use of this pattern allows the use of select attributes on xsl:apply-templates to be limited to those situations where the built-in processing is not adequate.
